These messrn:ers therefore departed, instructed to deliver the letter which he intrusted to their care, and what farther they were to add by word of mouth. Nicias in the mean time kept within the limits of his camp, more anxious to guard his shattered forces from annoyance than to plunge into fresh and spontaneous dangers. In the close of this summer, Euetion, an Athenian general, marched, in conjunction with Perdiccas and a large body of Thracians, against Amphipolis; yet could not render himself master of that city. But then, set- ting out from Imereum, he brought his triremes about into the Strymon, and blocked it up on the side of the river. And here this summer ended. In the beginning ot winter the messengers fiom Ni- cias arrived at Athens; where they gave such accounts of things as he had charged them to give, and resolved such questions as were asked them. They also deli- vered his letter; which the clerk of the State stood up and read aloud to the Athenians.
